channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: A look at the long-term goals of the U.S. and China from ongoing trade talks
item.description: NPR's A Martinez asks Elizabeth Economy, the Hargrove Senior Fellow at Stanford University's Hoover Institution, about long-term goals for the U.S. and China in their trade talks.

item.title: A wrap up of President Trump's trip to Scotland
item.description: President Trump has made big news during a 4-day visit to Scotland. He announced a new framework for U.S. trade with the EU and what could be a major recalibration of U.S. policy toward Gaza.

item.title: Gunman kills 4 people in Manhattan before killing himself, police say
item.description: Authorities in New York City say a man shot and killed four people, including a police officer, in midtown Manhattan on Monday. Officials say he then killed himself. NPR reports on the latest.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: A gunman killed four people before killing himself in Manhattan, a wrap up of President Trump's visit to Scotland, Israel continues to deliver some food into Gaza but aid groups say it's not enough.

item.title: Trump cuts deadline for Russia to reach peace deal with Ukraine
item.description: Trump said he's cutting short a 50-day deadline for the Kremlin to agree to a peace deal, saying Russia has less than two weeks to wind down its war in Ukraine or face huge new economic penalties.

item.title: Judge rules Trump administration cannot block Medicaid payments to Planned Parenthood
item.description: A federal judge on Monday ruled that Congress and the Trump administration are not allowed to stop Medicaid payments from going to Planned Parenthood.

item.title: New study finds certain lifestyle changes can help improve our brains as we age
item.description: A new study shows some of the strongest evidence yet that diet, exercise and other lifestyle changes can improve our brains — and reduce decline — as we age.

item.title: Where things stand two years after the Hollywood actors and writers strike
item.description: Two years ago, writers and actors in Hollywood were on strike. They say the deals they reached have been useful. But with less production these days, there are fewer jobs to go around.

item.title: Deion Sanders reveals he's beaten a life-threatening bout of bladder cancer
item.description: Deion Sanders, the University of Colorado's flamboyant football coach and former NFL star, says he's beaten a life-threatening bout of bladder cancer.

item.title: Food that Israel allows into Gaza only a fraction of what's needed, aid groups say
item.description: For a third day, Israel will be trucking in and allowing air drops of some food and aid into Gaza during daily 10-hour pauses in the fighting in its war in Gaza. But is this aid enough?
